articles.headline: Wrestling With Inequality, Some Conservatives Redraw Economic Blueprint
articles.snippet: A growing number of Republican politicians and theorists are challenging party orthodoxy on pocketbook issues, corporate power and government’s role.
articles.abstract: A growing number of Republican politicians and theorists are challenging party orthodoxy on pocketbook issues, corporate power and government’s role.
articles.lead_paragraph: More Republicans are coming to the view that economic inequality, or a lack of social mobility, is a problem in the United States — and that more can be done to enable families to attain or regain a middle-class life.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks to Recall 52 Million Airbag Inflaters
articles.snippet: The action covers airbags made by two companies and used by 12 automakers from 2000 to 2018. The parts were linked to seven injuries and one death.
articles.abstract: The action covers airbags made by two companies and used by 12 automakers from 2000 to 2018. The parts were linked to seven injuries and one death.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal auto safety regulators moved Tuesday toward a recall of about 52 million airbag inflaters used by a dozen major carmakers, calling the parts unsafe and susceptible to rupture.
articles.byline: By J. Edward Moreno and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Bread, Water and Peanut Butter: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Life in Jail
articles.snippet: Mr. Bankman-Fried, founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, has protested his conditions at Brooklyn’s Metropolitan Detention Center as he awaits trial on fraud charges.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried, founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, has protested his conditions at Brooklyn’s Metropolitan Detention Center as he awaits trial on fraud charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: A diet of bread, water and peanut butter. A laptop with no internet connection. And intermittent access to millions of pages of digital evidence.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Ex-Leader of Proud Boys Sentenced to 22 Years in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
articles.snippet: The prison term for Enrique Tarrio was the most severe penalty handed down so far to any of the more than 1,100 people charged in connection with the Capitol attack.
articles.abstract: The prison term for Enrique Tarrio was the most severe penalty handed down so far to any of the more than 1,100 people charged in connection with the Capitol attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, was sentenced on Tuesday to 22 years in prison for the central role he played in organizing a gang of his pro-Trump followers to attack the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and stop the peaceful transfer of presidential power.

articles.headline: Powered by A.I., Company Aims to Make Selling Easier for Retailers
articles.snippet: Lily AI matches online shoppers to the merchandise they’re looking for based on colloquial search terms, a welcome change for companies like Bloomingdale’s.
articles.abstract: Lily AI matches online shoppers to the merchandise they’re looking for based on colloquial search terms, a welcome change for companies like Bloomingdale’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Danielle Schmelkin went shopping online for something special to wear to her niece’s wedding in 2021, she was looking for “a very specific type of dress based on trends I had seen recently.”

articles.headline: In Its First Monopoly Trial of Modern Internet Era, U.S. Sets Sights on Google
articles.snippet: The 10-week trial, set to begin Tuesday, amps up efforts to rein in Big Tech by targeting the core search business that turned Google into a $1.7 trillion behemoth.
articles.abstract: The 10-week trial, set to begin Tuesday, amps up efforts to rein in Big Tech by targeting the core search business that turned Google into a $1.7 trillion behemoth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: As Abortion Laws Drive Obstetricians From Red States, Maternity Care Suffers
articles.snippet: Some doctors who handle high-risk pregnancies are fleeing restrictive abortion laws. Idaho has been particularly hard hit.
articles.abstract: Some doctors who handle high-risk pregnancies are fleeing restrictive abortion laws. Idaho has been particularly hard hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, doctors who handle high-risk pregnancies are disappearing from Idaho — part of a wave of obstetricians fleeing restrictive abortion laws and a hostile state legislature. Dr. Caitlin Gustafson, a family doctor who also delivers babies in the tiny mountain town of McCall, is among those left behind, facing a lonely and uncertain future.

articles.headline: Google Turns to a Steady Old Hand to Fight Antitrust Charges
articles.snippet: The tech giant is facing the greatest legal threat in its history, and hopes the stolid approach of Kent Walker, its top lawyer, will once again prevail.
articles.abstract: The tech giant is facing the greatest legal threat in its history, and hopes the stolid approach of Kent Walker, its top lawyer, will once again prevail.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the government started an antitrust investigation into Google, one of the company’s top lawyers, Kent Walker, said the solution was not a charm offensive. Google just needed to explain how its business functioned.

articles.headline: Why Republicans Could Impeach a Liberal Judge Before She’s Heard a Case
articles.snippet: Republicans in Wisconsin have floated impeaching a newly seated liberal State Supreme Court justice who is threatening conservatives’ grip on state politics.
articles.abstract: Republicans in Wisconsin have floated impeaching a newly seated liberal State Supreme Court justice who is threatening conservatives’ grip on state politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans in Wisconsin are coalescing around the prospect of impeaching a newly seated liberal justice on the state’s Supreme Court, whose victory in a costly, high-stakes election this spring swung the court in Democrats’ favor and threatened the G.O.P.’s iron grip on state politics.

articles.headline: Bedtime Check-Ins and Verbal Abuse: Women’s Life in Spanish Soccer
articles.snippet: More than a dozen women described sexism ranging from paternalism to verbal abuse. “What you really need is a good man,” a former national captain said players were told.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen women described sexism ranging from paternalism to verbal abuse. “What you really need is a good man,” a former national captain said players were told.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, when Beatriz Álvarez landed the job as president of the Spanish women’s soccer league, she asked to meet the chief of the country’s soccer federation by videoconference, she said, so she could remain home with her newborn child.
articles.byline: By Rachel Chaundler, Sarah Hurtes and Jeré Longman
